title: Dungeons & Dragons Boxed Set
description: The original Dungeons & Dragons boxed set, published in 1974 by Tactical Studies Rules, introduced the world to an entirely new genre of gaming: the tabletop role-playing game. Created by Gary Gygax and Dave Arneson, it combined medieval fantasy, improvisational storytelling, and tactical wargaming into a groundbreaking system that encouraged collaborative adventure.

With just three small booklets, it opened the gates to a limitless world of imagination and heroic quests. This humble beginning laid the foundation for what would become a global phenomenon and an enduring legacy in gaming history.

title: Supplement I: Greyhawk
description: Greyhawk, released in 1975, was the first official expansion to the original D&D ruleset. Co-authored by Gary Gygax and Rob Kuntz, this supplement introduced a host of innovations that would become foundational to the game, including new character classes like the thief and paladin, expanded combat rules, and a trove of additional monsters, spells, and magical items. Drawing from the legendary Greyhawk campaign, it infused the game with greater depth and variety, offering Dungeon Masters and players new dimensions of adventure. Greyhawk marked a pivotal step in the evolution of D&D, shaping its identity for years to come.

title: Supplement II: Blackmoor
description: Blackmoor, released in 1975, expanded the original game's horizons with new rules, character classes, and the first published role-playing game adventure. Compiled by Dave Arneson, co-creator of D&D, it introduced the monk and assassin classes, underwater adventuring rules, and innovative gameplay elements that pushed the boundaries of fantasy role-playing. Blackmoor also featured the first detailed campaign setting, offering players a glimpse into Arneson's own legendary home campaign. This supplement marked a crucial step in evolving D&D into a richer, more immersive experience.

title: Supplement III: Eldritch Wizardry
description: Eldritch Wizardry, published in 1976, delved deep into the arcane and esoteric corners of fantasy role-playing. It introduced psionics, artifacts, and demons to the game, significantly expanding the magical and supernatural elements available to players. The supplement unveiled powerful new spells, the druid class, and infamous artifacts like the Hand and Eye of Vecna, adding layers of mystery and danger to campaigns. Eldritch Wizardry pushed the boundaries of imagination and complexity, cementing D&D's reputation as a game of limitless adventure.

title: Supplement IV: Gods, Demi-Gods & Heroes
description: Gods, Demigods & Heroes, released in 1976, brought myth and legend into the hands of adventurers. This supplement presented detailed pantheons from real-world mythologies—Greek, Norse, Egyptian, and more—alongside fantasy deities from popular fiction. Designed as a powerful tool for Dungeon Masters, it provided stats, lore, and abilities for divine beings, allowing them to shape their worlds with godlike influence.
Supplement IV served as both a reference and inspiration, blurring the line between mythology and fantasy in early D&D campaigns.

title: Supplement V: Swords & Spells
description: Swords & Spells, published in 1976, introduced a set of mass combat rules tailored for large-scale fantasy battles. Designed as a bridge between D&D and its wargaming roots, this supplement allowed players to command entire armies while retaining the flavor of individual character actions. It translated spells and creatures into miniature warfare mechanics, offering a new dimension of tactical gameplay.
Swords & Spells was the final official supplement for the original D&D line, rounding out the game's formative era with epic, battlefield-level scope.

title: Monster Manual
description: The Advanced Dungeons & Dragons First Edition Monster Manual, published in 1977, was the very first hardcover rulebook for AD&D and marked a significant evolution in tabletop role-playing. Compiled and written by Gary Gygax, it introduced a comprehensive bestiary of over 350 creatures, ranging from classic mythological beasts to wholly original fantasy monsters. The book set the standard for monster presentation in future editions, with detailed statistics, descriptions, and evocative illustrations. It became an essential tool for Dungeon Masters, laying the foundation for decades of storytelling and adventure in the D&D multiverse.

title: Player's Handbook
description: The Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 1st Edition Player’s Handbook, released in 1978, was a cornerstone of the AD&D system and a pivotal evolution of the game. Compiled and written by Gary Gygax, it provided players with comprehensive rules for character creation, spellcasting, equipment, and gameplay mechanics, establishing a new standard of depth and structure in tabletop roleplaying. Rich with iconic illustrations and dense with lore, it empowered players to fully immerse themselves in complex, imaginative worlds. This handbook became an essential resource at the table and remains a beloved classic in the history of the hobby.

title: Dungeon Master's Guide
description: The Advanced Dungeons & Dragons 1st Edition Dungeon Master’s Guide, published in 1979, is the definitive companion for running immersive and richly detailed AD&D campaigns. Written by Gary Gygax, it equips Dungeon Masters with rules, advice, magic items, encounter tables, and behind-the-scenes mechanics essential for world-building and adjudication. Overflowing with arcane wisdom and classic illustrations, the guide opens the doors to limitless adventures and creative storytelling. Its depth and authority have made it a cornerstone of the hobby and a treasured artifact of RPG history.

title: The Rogues Gallery
description: The AD&D First Edition Rogues Gallery, published by TSR in 1980, is a supplement designed to assist Dungeon Masters by providing a wide array of pre-generated non-player characters (NPCs). Compiled by Brian Blume with contributions from TSR staff, it features everything from lowly henchmen to powerful villains, ready for immediate use in any campaign. The book also includes random NPC generation tables and even showcases some of the famous characters from the original creators' own home games. It serves as a versatile resource for adding depth, unpredictability, and memorable encounters to AD&D adventures.

title: Deities & Demigods
description: The AD&D First Edition Deities & Demigods, published by TSR in 1980, is a hardcover supplement that presents mythological and fantasy pantheons for use in Advanced Dungeons & Dragons campaigns. Compiled by James M. Ward with help from Robert J. Kuntz, the book details gods, heroes, and monsters from a variety of real-world mythologies and fictional universes. Each deity is given game statistics, lore, and artwork, allowing Dungeon Masters to incorporate divine powers and legendary figures into their worlds. It became a classic resource, notable for its ambitious scope and early inclusion of licensed settings like Cthulhu Mythos and Melniboné.
